title: Gallstone Pancreatitis
diagnosis_topic: Acute pancreatitis triggered by transient obstruction of the common bile duct by gallstones
setup_script: A 40-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of epigastric pain radiating to the back accompanied by nausea and vomiting. She has a history of gallstones.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 37.9 C.
Epigastric tenderness without rebound; no jaundice initially.
Serum lipase 800 U/L (elevated), AST/ALT moderately elevated; bilirubin 2 mg/dL indicating biliary obstruction.
Gallstones in gallbladder; common bile duct slightly dilated but no stones visualized.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates aggressive IV hydration and analgesia
dynamic_flow.reply: Lactated Ringer's infusion started; pain managed with opioids.
Prevents pancreatic stimulation; NG tube if vomiting persists.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults GI for ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: Indicated if cholangitis or persistent common bile duct obstruction; otherwise not urgently needed.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays cholecystectomy until after pancreatitis resolves
dynamic_flow.reply: Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during index hospitalization reduces recurrence.
Watch for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts and systemic inflammatory response syndrome.
Not indicated unless infection or cholangitis present.
Ranson or BISAP scores help stratify severity and guide ICU admission.
Low-fat diet after recovery and avoidance of alcohol.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of gallstone pancreatitis with elevated lipase and ultrasound
Early fluid resuscitation and pain control
Determination of need for ERCP and timing of cholecystectomy
Monitoring for complications and avoiding unnecessary antibiotics
Patient education on diet and recurrence prevention
